issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) says “Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter” but the actual controller API in both the template and the solution uses Consumer<List<Person>> for PersonController methods. This is a wording/parameter-type mismatch in the problem description that could confuse students about the expected generic type for the consumer parameter when implementing the PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) for the PersonController methods so the description matches the template and solution signatures and avoids confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (documentation) mistakenly refers to the callback parameter type for the person-related controller methods as Consumer<List<Note>> (lines referencing notes), while both the template and the solution use Consumer<List<Person>> in the PersonController methods. This inconsistent identifier (Note vs Person) for the same conceptual entity (the list passed to the consumer callback for person operations) can confuse students about the expected types and mappings between requirements and the code they must implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement text to consistently reference Person (not Note) for the callback type. Replace `Consumer<List<Note>>` with `Consumer<List<Person>>` in the problem statement (and any other documentation lines that mention the incorrect type). This aligns the documentation with the template and solution code and removes the mismatch students might otherwise need to resolve mentally.
